reviewText: The opening prologue to Dune, read in the film by actress Virginia Madsen (playing Princess Irulan, daughter of the Emperor Shaddam IV) could only be incomprehensible to a five-year-old, it seems quite clear to me and I've seen the film many times.  C'mon Leonard Maltin, grow a pair of ears would you?  Also, reading the novel might have helped, given that Dune is only based upon one of the greatest SF novels of the 20th Century.  The film's still not that dense, it would have been much more confusing if they had actually stuck to the novel anyway more slavishly, which would have been impossible.  To Leonard Maltin, I say, as Feyd-Rautha Harkonnen, with fury in my voice, "the righteous!!?"  If only the righteous could read.

reviewText: A beginning is a very delicate time. In 1984, the long awaited film version of Frank Herbert's epic novel Dune came to the silver screen. What happened next? The worst box office disaster in history! Sad to say it, but mostly everyone who saw Dune hated it except for the few who actually read the book! I've always loved this movie but if I ever said that in public I was usually beaten with large rocks or a baseball bat. This review isn't really about the story of the film or it's direction. Its about the confusing truth of their actually being two editions of the 1984 film version of dune.Now here is where the entire true purpose to this review comes in. Many may wonder, "why was I watching this on Sci-Fi channel and the director was Alan Smithee instead of David Lynch?" Well little Jimmy, the answer is complicated. David Lynch knew when he made Dune he was in trouble and cut the film down incredibly to make it fit the desired time limit. Lynch was slightly pleased with this cut of the film and hoped that that would be the last he would have to do with it... Wrong!A few years when Dune finally was on TV, a special edition version was prepared containing an HOUR of extra footage. A new narration covers the film and practically spells out every bit of information to the audience this time. The studios were ready to show it when suddenly David Lynch says "Woa woa, I liked it the way it was!" and refuses to have credit for this new longer version. The studio then takes out Lynch's name and replaces it with the fake Alan Smithee who doesn't exist. With me so far?The version of Dune available on DVD and VHS is the David Lynch version which in my opinion actually works better than the longer version. It cuts to the chase and doesn't drag as badly as Smithee's version does.  For those of you who have never seen the Alan Smithee version, its not available to buy but it's shown on the Sci-Fi channel twice a year so there you go!So, even though critics bombed it, audiences hated it, and David Lynch disowned the longer version, I still love this movie for some mysterious reason! If you're the type who likes weird artistic movies like 12 Monkeys, 2001, or Blade Runner, you will probably enjoy this. Also anime fans, this is right up your alley! For all you other people, get the hell out of here!p.s. Toto's score is a masterpiece! Yea... of all bands... Toto...
summary: Why does it say David Lynch then Alan Smithee? I'll tell ya!

reviewText: Trying to squeeze the entire book into a mere two hours was a mistake from the beginning.  The subtelties and intricacies that make up the story are largely absent in this rushed collection of events.  Many of the main characters have only a few quick lines and are then quickly shoved aside by the action.David Lynch's portrayal of the Dune universe is a pseudo-psychedelic vision tinged with acid green.  Since when is Thufir Hawat's anti-venom produced by a very skinny white cat?  Why are the Sardakaur portrayed as big monsters wearing baggy silver space suits?  They swat at people with their big arms, have green gas swirling behind their faceplates, and run about like claymation technozombies.  What a disgrace!  The emperor's elite troops are supposed to be rugged veteran swordfighters, NOT funked up astronauts from the fourth planet of the Braxomeel system.  The mentats look awful.  They have munchkinland hair and wear bright red lipstick.  Feyd Rautha should not have been played by Sting with his greased up cherry-orange koolaid hair and silly adolescent sneer.  Why does pulling tubes out of a still suit cause someone to bleed to death?  Ridiculous!To cap it all off, the Fremen get rid of their knives in the final battle and start using wierd boxes that shoot mysterious cosmic rays.  In the book, it was all sword fighting!  The battle between the two toughest armies in the known universe was spoiled.  The silver suited Sardakaur morons run around in circles as they are all blasted away by magical beams of quasi-protons.What an insult to a great and sophisticated work of literature!  Half of the important scenes are edited out or cut to a sliver and yet the script includes a scene where a navigator visits the emperor in its spice fish tank.  David Lynch's Dune is an attempt to compress too much into too little and it fails to capture the enigmatic spirit of Arrakis despite a dazzling array of special effects.
summary: Long book, Short movie, Bad Idea

reviewText: The "Spice Melange" extends life and existence as people know it in the year 10191 AD. However, this precious spice is only available on one planet and that is planet Arrakis. Also known as DUNE!There are two families who want to gain control of spice production because the one who controls the spice, will, indeed, control the whole universe! The spice is mined on Arrakis but there are HUGE sand worms that try to guard it for themselves. Be careful of WORM SIGN!The families that war it out over the spice are: House Atreides, home of Duke Leto (Prochnow), Lady Jessica, a Bene Gesserit handmaiden & their son, Paul (MacLachlan). The Atreides reside on planet Caladan. House Harkonnen, comprised of Baron Vladimir Harkonnen (McMillen), Feyd-Rautha (Sting) & The Beast Rabban, reside on planet Giedi Prime.On planet Kaitain resides Jose Ferrer as the Emperor of the Universe, Shaddam & his daughter, Princess Irulan played by Virginia Madsen.This story is focused on intergalactic warrior, young Paul Atreides & his messianic rise to leadership by coming into his own, so to speak. Due in part to an old prophecy regarding a man that will be above all other men.The circa 1984 visual/special effects are STILL stunning even by today's standards, the soundtrack is by Toto, and some of the monsters created for this film, like "The Guildmaster" were by the likes of E.T.'s Carlo Rambaldi.This film heads an all-star cast with the ones mentioned above plus - Sean Young as Chani the Fremen, Linda Hunt as Fremen Shadout Mapes, Brad Dourif as Piter De Vries, Patrick Stewart as Gurney, Max Von Sydow as Dr. Kynes, and even David Lynch makes an appearance as a Spice mining worker!Even a 5 or 6 year old little girl by the name of Alicia Witt from "Urban Legend" & "Two Weeks Notice" gets her first big movie role, her SAG card as Paul's little sister, Alia, and one of the best lines in the film - "And how can this be? For he IS the Kwisatz Haderack!"The alternate 2 hour 57 minute version on the flipside of the theatrical cut was the cut for television. As many fans of Dune know, this 'extended' version was disowned by Lynch, who insisted his name be replaced by that famous Hollywood pseudonym "Alan Smithee" the name used by directors whose films were taken away and recut against their wishes.PROS: The extended version is FINALLY released in DVD widescreen format. The circa 1984 set design and special effects are still, indeed, SPECIAL!CONS: Lynch's version of Dune is either a "love it or hate it" epic film. If viewers are expecting the mythic 4 hour "David Lynch preferred" version that is rumored to be sitting in a vault, don't get your hopes up. This version is indeed, a MYTH.Deleted scenes include the highly debated and much removed Thufir death scene where Thufir is administered a lethal dose of poison by the Harkonnen's and has a kind of sexually orgasmic death.Regardless, if you like Lynch, sci-fi or just weird set design and effects, I highly recommend this film to you!Happy Watching, Unpleasant Dreams & May The Spice Be With You!!!
summary: The Spice MUST FLOW!!! David Lynch's Dada-esque "DUNE" Finally Given A Respectable DVD Release

reviewText: The theatrical version was just awful.  Most people who are David Lynch fans--which I am not--agree that "Dune" is a terrible movie.  It's not just the huge liberties he took with the story (tho' the DeLaurentises maybe more responsible for that than Lynch, to be fair), its that Lynch clearly had no understanding of the source material.  Frank Herbert's books were subtle, nuanced explorations of some of the most basic and universal themes of the human experience.  This film ignores what made the book great in exchange for a Lynch horror-show where the gross, disgusting and perverted take center stage.But again, it's the liberties with the story that really ruin this movie.  The entire rationale for the conspiracy between the "Padishah" Emperor and the Harkonnens was that the Atreides were developing an army that was superior to the Sardaukar troops with which the Corrinos had made themselves the Imperial House.  The whole idea behind the culture of the Imperium was that development of HUMAN potential, not "weirding modules."  Duke Leto's new army was built around that principle.  Incorporating Bene Gesserit techniques, Leto was constructing a group of warriors capable by sheer human effort to overcome any enemy.His son would combine that training with the incredibly tough Fremen, infuse them with religious fanaticism and then defeat Shaddam IV and conquer the "Known Universe."Instead we get "weirding modules."  Basically, magic boxes that blow stuff up.  There is absolute NOTHING about this in the books; and indeed, to reiterate, it runs completely AGAINST every theme in Herbert's work.Combining the drastic plot changes with Lynch's bizarre sensibilities and fetishes and you get the gigantic mess that this movie is.Kyle MacLachlan's insipid, wimpy performance is another huge flaw.  There is no WAY any one who's read these books can believe, for a minute, that he could be a guerilla leader, let alone an Emperor, a Messiah or transcendent being.  It gives me the giggles to think about.  Alec Newman's utterly convincing performance in the two mini-series as Paul Muad'Dib (and "The Preacher") is far superior to MacLachlan's in every way.  Newman looks like he could have just stepped out of the desert.  MacLachlan looks like he just stepped out of an Armani suit with a $200 haircut.  This movie showcases why he's always remained in the cinematic bush leagues.  He simply doesn't have the talent as an actor for any significant role.  (That he's now gotten fat doesn't help.)Francesca Annis's stiff, unsympathetic Jessica is a bore.  Jurgen Prochnow, one of Germany's greatest actors, looks here as if he's constantly biting back a laugh.  Even the performance of Kenneth MacMillian as Baron Harkonnen, though praised by some, is a show case of just how badly an actor can overact.  (Even Susan Sarandon doesn't come close in her off-kilter performance in the second mini-series.)  Jose Ferrer has simply no credibility as the ruler of multi-galactic empire.  The only performance that isn't ridiculous is Sian Phillip's Reverend Mother Gaius Helen Mohiam.  But she's just a brilliant actor stuck in a huge mess of a film.  After her stunning work in "I, Claudius" fans of the latter can only cringe at the total waste of her talents.The only real fun in the movie is Sting's performance as Feyd-Rautha.  Mr. Sumner seems to be the only one who's aware that he's in a badly done farce.  He plays it to the hilt and his baroquely campy performance is great fun.  But Feyd is a minor character and Sting simply can't lighten the leaden pomposity of Lynch, MacLachlan & company.  But he is great fun to watch.It has been said that the "extended version" greatly improves upon the theatrical.  Nonsense.  It's just makes for longer, more excruciating cinematic torture.There's only one version of "Dune" as far as fans of the book should be concerned, and that is John Harrison's mini-series made for Sci-Fi channel.  It's 4.5 hours long and sticks faithfully to the themes, if not always literally, in Herbert's book.  The CG special effects are far superior to the 20 year old special effects in Lynch's disaster.  The CGI sandworms, in particularly, do not bear the phallic aspect that caused so much laughter in the theaters when I saw it.  They actually look how most people had imagined them.Skip this attempt to make even more dollars off this gigantic flop and buy the two Sci-Fi Channel mini-series.  They deliver the essence of the original trilogy far better than Lynch did and the modern special effects--a good deal of which are contributed by the same company that did the CG effects for Babylon 5, Netter Digital--are simply stunning.  Not only that, the mini-series are filmed without that "brown soup" that covers every frame of Lynch's movie (the movie was shot through a brown light filter to give a "darker" more "menacing" look, it failed; instead the movie just looks even more ridiculous).I remember an interview where MacLachlan stated that the entire cast and crew had "signed on for three movies."  Thankfully this movie's "Heaven's Gate" type failure ensured that Lynch and Co. wouldn't get the chance to mar the other two books of the trilogy.As a side note: the complete failure at the box office of this film bankrupted the DeLaurentises, putting a halt to more giggle fests from the family who'd become the Kings of Schlock (Flash Gordon anyone?).AVOID!!!BTW, for those of you worrying about the Aspect Ratio of the extended version, there's no reason to.  The movie was shot in 70mm, if memory serves; even if it was only 35mm that presents no problem.  Universal certainly will have used that film from which to make the transfer to digital.  There seems to be a basic misunderstanding of "anamorphic" by many reviewers.  Anamorphic ensures that the movie will adapt to your TV's screen, whether it's 16X9 or 4X3.  The 1:2.35 ratio, however, indicates that it's been formatted for 16X9 sets.  Those of you with 4X3s will be looking at a small picture with big black lines.
summary: Just awful--making it longer doesn't make it better

reviewText: They are both here at last, folks!  Have you been waiting eagerly for years?Lynch's original theatrical cut suffered from too many trims in order to reduce the running time.  It features an intelligent script faithful to the Herbert novels (though the business about the Weirding Modules using the sound equivalent of Killing Thoughts is a pure and silly invention of Lynch himself.)  The performances are (mostly) fantastic, the sets, costumes and camera work are suberb, the music by Toto and Brian Eno is breathtaking, and the special effects are pretty bad.  Reviews back in 1984 stated, rightly, that it would probably be incomprehensible to anyone who had not read the book.Then there's the ghastly, embarassing, dumbed-down version prepared by Universal TV.  It includes quite a bit of extra footage that Lynch wasn't able to include in the theatrical version, longer versions of some scenes and others (like the drowning of a sand trout and the fight with Jamus) which appear only in this version.  However, the chalk-drawing prologue is trash, the new narration is pure garbage (the guy sounds like he stepped out of an ADR session for a granola commercial,) the re-edit on Shaddam's dialogue with the Guild Navigator is a joke (did Universal really think that no one in America would understand the term "House Atreides?") and the Dune Muzak which plays underneath every scene (without any relation to what is happening on the screen) is also a shame.  No, Lynch did not record the narration for the TV version.  He does appear in both versions as the radio operator aboard the spice harvester (and has several lines, both onscreen and off.)  Lynch rightfully removed his name from this complete mess.  Did Universal think that "A Alan Smithee Film" is a representation of correct grammar?  Did they really need to use the same shot of a flying Harkonnen ship about 6 times to represent anyone in the film travelling anywhere by ship?One thing about Lynch is his amazing use of sound - LISTEN to his films, sometime.  Amazing.  The TV version sounds like two radios tuned to different stations.Those of you with nice movie software might want to spend an afternoon doing a re-edit of both versions.  The theatrical cut plays much better if you plug in the extra footage from the TV version and the new collection of deleted scenes.Nice documentaries, and the further collection of deleted scenes includes the death of Thufir Hawat.  No participation by Lynch, alas.
summary: Do you prefer the Bastardized Theatrical Release or the Incompetent Extended TV Version?

reviewText: The most interesting thing about this movie is that you can see how George Lucas ripped off the original book, 'Dune' by Frank Herbert, for his 'Star Wars' series. By the time Lucas gets to filming 'The Phantom Menace,' he has graduated to David Lynch's level of making sci-fi movies like 'Dune.' These kind of movies are filled with sword fighting, endless expository monologues, stilted dialogue, worries over economic warfare and pained attempts to invoke classical and religious themes. This movie shows Kyle Machlan teaching ragtag sand dwellers how to tear apart stone by making resonating sounds with their voices. Oh, and it has big worms.

reviewText: Well.  Time to write a review of this on Amazon.  So many things to say.  A beginning is a delicate time.  Well, lets state the obvious first and foremost.This movie was a flop.  A bomb.  A disaster.  It cost a great deal of money to make and it made almost nothing at the box office.  This was due to a number of reasons.  One, in the early eighties, science fiction was considered very uncool.  So that any young dude in the early eighties worth his salt wouldn't be caught dead going to this movie.  The other matter is that any of those young dudes who DID happen to wander into this movie probably had to wonder just what the hell was going on.Dune is very challenging science fiction that almost might be considered the work of a genius.  It is far more complex and interweaving than the plot for something like "Star Wars" for example.  By that, I'm not saying that Star Wars was a bad movie, indeed, it was a very profitable one (unlike Dune).  It is just that from my viewpoint, it is incredible that this movie was even created at all, considering the usual attitude of movie studios toward complex plots of any kind whatsoever.  In fact, I would go so far as to venture the guess that this movie being a flop set a standard for one dimensional movie plot lines for years to come.  A movie must make a profit, the dumber the movie, the bigger the profit.Anyway, the point is this movie somehow, against all odds, WAS made.  And the director, to add to the weirdness, was that master of weirdness (the weirding way?) himself, David Lynch.  Right away, Lynch went about "weirding up" the plot, adding his own eccentric touches (the cheesy sound weapons aren't in the book at all they were put there by Lynch maybe he thought the young dudes would find sound weapons cool).With David Lynch at the helm, production went forward.  It went very well.  Until they ran out of money and time.  This is why the final battle sequence is so wretched.  The editing in particular was done at the last minute and wow, does it stink.  Note how in the final battle the soundtrack changes at a machine gun rate, the trademark of poor editing.Despite it all, it remains the BEST VERSION OF DUNE AROUND.  And for this, I am thankful.  If this movie had never been made, I would never have started reading Frank Herberts novels.  And that, I think, is the real point of any movie version of a book.  To get the kids READING.

reviewText: An entire universe was addicted to a drug, ruled by machines, and liberated by religious crusades. A unique drug, the spice melange is the product of monstrous and gigantic worms that live in the sands of the dry planet Dune. Addicted to the drug, the people become apathetic and leave the machines to do their work, including the mental work. In time, they become slaves of men who control the machines until they liberate themselves during the religious crusades.  After thousand of years schools were created to reeducate them, two of which survived for each gender.The movie Dune is the product of the hard work of the producers working together with Frank Herbert, the author of the series of six books. It barely touches on the first book since the layers are many, complicated and esoteric at times. I have seen every version of the movies, including the TV version, and the newest versions which include some of the other books. I cannot have enough of this movie: it is my favorite movie ever; nothing comes close--in my opinion--to rival the quality of the acting, the plot, the production, the special effects and the (theme) music.To enjoy the movie better, I recommend reading at least the first book of the series titled Dune by Frank Herbert.

reviewText: Dune (Extended Edition) has been a long time coming. When the original movie was released in the theatres running at over two hours, the film was a financial flop. However, over the years David Lynch's adaptation of the novel has achieved a kind of cult status with its incredible set design and largely faithful translation of the book.The Extended Edition was originally released only on TV several years later without Lynch's approval -- so much so that he asked that his name be pulled from the credits and replaced by the infamous "Alan Smithee" (an approved name for directors who want to distance themselves from a finished project). Until now, this extended edition has never been available on DVD so this then is the first chance for most people to have a look at an alternate version of this classic.So how does this Extended Edition stand up? Well, in short, good in parts and really bad in others.First the bad -- the film opens with the original Princess Irulan  narration replaced by an overly-long and unnecessary narrative by someone who sounds like a Southern gentleman (think Colonel Sanders). This narration is accompanied by, believe it or not, production photos. Even worse, Colonel Sanders' obtrusive narration goes on throughout the movie. Not a good start at all. The other bad thing is that most of the music has been rescored and re-arranged even in the non-extended scenes. For example, the first scene where the Guild Navigator visits the Emperor has some added music from another scene -- the original scene did not have any music at all.Now on to the good -- once the film gets under way, most of the additional scenes actually do add more to the movie. In fact, almost every major scene in Dune has a slightly extended bit, with a little more action and a surprising amount of character development. For example, going back to the first meeting between the Emperor and the Guild Navigator, the conversation that precedes this, between the Bene Gesserit advisor and the Emperor, has been slightly extended, making the Bene Gesserit a more human and doubting character. Then, later in the movie, there's a short scene which shows how the Fremen extract the Water of Life from a juvenile sandworm.Overall, the extended edition, while still a long way from being a good film, does add a lot of interesting bits for the curious Dune fan. Hopefully there'll be a Special Extended Edition which does it right and puts back the Irulan narration while leaving in the extended scenes.Oh yes, this Extended Edition DVD comes with the original version as well so you can enjoy Lynch's far superior version when you're tired of the extended version. Also worth mentioning is that this DVD comes in a very nice metal presentation case -- much better than any metal case I've owned so far.

reviewText: David Lynch's "Dune" has held up extremely well over the years, far better than I ever would have expected.Part of the reason, I think, is the choice of directors.  Frank Herbert's "Dune" is one of those unfilmable novels (in fact, it makes "Lord of the Rings" look like child's play), and David Lynch manages to capture at least the bare essentials of the novel -- the sense of pessimism, dark urgency, and atmospherics.  The latter is a sorely-missed quality, and "Dune the Movie" holds up very well compared to the post-movie theatrical wasteland of the early 21st century, and such films as "Planet of the Apes," "Star Wars Episode 1" and "The Time Machine."Viewers would be well-advised to try and read the book first -- again, like "LOTR," some background is almost a necessity before attempting the film.  The story is just too complex to translate well to the big screen, so if you haven't read the book then you might find yourself simply relaxing and soaking up the (very well done) atmosphere and the visuals.I'm very thankful that this film wasn't made sometime in the past five years.  It would be painful to see Frank Herbert's genius placed on the chopping block of some money-grubbing producer and made into (yet another) CGI-based carnival freakshow.  Enjoy this film for what it is, a "true" re-imagining of the novel "Dune" as seen by David Lynch's somewhat twisted imagination.

reviewText: I've heard of this film for years, but not until recently, did I realize how much of a dud this film was considered by critics, and even by the director himself.  After all, I've never heard of a film this epic, with this kind of budget, being pretty much disowned by it's director. Even to the extent that he requested his name be removed from the credits. This immediately intrigued me. Is this movie THAT bad? I had to see for myself.Now first off, I want to say that I didn't read the novel before watching the film. Again, I've heard of this film for years, but quite honestly, didn't know it was a film adaptation of a novel until recently. That being said, I know that I might get some criticism from die hard fans of the novel and/or of this film. In fact, I might come off sounding ignorant while reviewing this film simply because I haven't read the novel. There's absolutely no doubt that I would have understood a lot more, and perhaps enjoyed it a lot more than I did if I had.The prologue that begins the film tries to explain the overall back story, but for me, all it did was confuse the heck out of me. The crazy names, places, and events the narrator were describing seemed like it was in a different language. For me, it was a lot of stuff to take in all at once and most of it went over my head. Now I'm not saying I'm the smartest guy out there, but I'm not a moron. And I can say there's been very few films that I've just felt lost while watching. But in the beginning of this film, that's what I was. Even with the beginning narrative, all the character's names sounded like made-up gibberish, I still didn't know who was who,  and I still didn't know what the heck they were all talking about. But as the movie went along, I began to get the jest of most of it. Even though there's a bunch of things said, that just seem nonsensical: "He who can destroy a thing, controls a thing" or "Try looking into that place where you dare not look. You'll find me there, staring back at you." There's a lot lines like these where I just chuckled to myself. Part because of the actual verbiage and part of the over-dramatization of the sentences themselves.Now as far as the complexity and weirdness of the plot, this film equally matches that with it's elaborate sets, costumes, and special effects. There are undoubtedly some of the craziest costumes I've ever seen in a film. Weird hairdos, nasty warts and blisters, unbelievably bushy eyebrows, tubes in nostrils, and leather outfits galore.. This movie has it all. And special effects aren't too bad for its time either I suppose. Though I can't say I'm overly impressed. Especially the shield effect that was used, which was just way too bulky and box-looking. It looked just plain bad. However, for the most part, this is what I enjoyed most about the film. The crazy costumes and effects.As far as the cast goes, it contains a decent array of actors, including Patrick Stewart, Brad Dourif,and Max Von Sydow. But actually, none of the cast really stood out to me as far as great performances go. For me, a lot of the characters were played overly dramatic, almost Shakespearian. Maybe that was the point, but I thought that it was a bit too much. But again, this is Dune. I don't think the words "too much" are in this film's vocabulary. After all, in one scene you have Sting holding a cage with a cat and rat tied together, while a real ugly fat guy is telling the other ugly bushy eyed-brow guy that he's has to milk a cat daily otherwise he dies. Yeah. I rest my case.Ultimately, I think what hurt this movie the most was that there was simply too much information crammed into the film. Too much plot, too much explanation. And too much use of narration to try to speed up the story. It just didn't work. Characters and their relationships with other characters seemed hurried to develop far too quickly. Especially towards the end where it just felt like a hurried, jumbled mess. That's why in most cases, I think its difficult to adapt novels into movies, especially this kind of novel.  Because you risk ruining the film by leaving too much stuff out, or ruining it by cramming too much stuff in. I think this should have been at least a 2 part film, perhaps a trilogy, much like Lord of the Rings. With that, you would have plenty of time to develop a story and characters. And I think because of that slower pace, it would have been a lot easier to understand for those who hadn't read the novel first. So is this film as bad as critics said it was? Is it worthy of having its director David Lynch basically disowning it? Well no, I don't think it is as bad as that. But its certainly not great by any means. The crazy weird plot and characters aren't really the problem. Its just with so much information and plot to absorb while seeing all this stuff happening on screen, it makes it hard on grab onto. Its clear that this movie has a certain fan base, but the way the film is made, it makes it almost impossible to win over a causal moviegoer, or anyone that hasn't read the book first. And that's what I recommend for anyone who's interested in watching this film for the first time. Try reading the book first. This will undoubtedly help your cause.
summary: 2.5 Stars: Dune: Such a simple title for a not-so-simple film.

reviewText: Like a fine wine this film has aged very well.  While viewing it, you would never guess it was made in 1984.  Dune is filled with impressive and futuristic images in an artsy fartsy kind of way. Yes the plot is beyond  complicated, as most of David Lynch's movies usually are, but the  characters carry the weight of the complex nature of this film and turn it  into a highly fascinating look at the year 10,000, chock full o' worms!  The whole plot centers around "the spice" and how it is an  essential part of everyone's "diet" so to speak. The spice must  flow afterall and the evil forces are out to control all spice production.  In the processs, the worms are being aggrevated and we can't have that!  One thing leads to another, the good guys win, the bad guys die and are  overthrown and guy gets girl, guy has self-realization, guy rides big worm across the desert, the end.  You know, your everyday run of the mill  type movie.If you have enough patience to make it through to the end,  you will feel like you have made this mystical journey with Paul Atreides,  in his world, on his terms.  Or you will feel overwhelmed and exhausted and  scream out "GET OUT OF MY MIND!".
summary: Dune: The "Excalibur" of Sci Fi Movies.

reviewText: This Dino DeLaurentis production of Frank Herbert's 'Dune' is perhaps one of the more unusual science fiction movies out there.  I love this film for its visual style and appeal; It is a future where thinking machines are outlawed and depicted in an italian renaissance style.  The actors, some quite noteworthy, fit into the style of this film.This film has received most criticism for its distortion of the plot and poor character development.  I don't mind this too much; it is an intertaining and grand film.DVD EDITION: What bothers me is the recording format for this DVD.  Resolution is compromised because it is letterboxed and is truly a waste to see on wide aspect televisions.  Making it fit the screen compromises resolution quite a bit; this is why I only give it 3 stars, when as a film it deserves more.  I wish Universal would release a dual layer edition with proper 16:9 screen support.  Also, the transfer has poor contrast and has some artifacts.NEW! BLU RAY EDITION:  The high resolution detail is very good and I'm able to see things I never could before.  The print is grainy with intermittent defects on the far right of the picture.  The main thing that is strange about this cheaply made BLU-RAY edition is that the sound mastering is very strange.  Incidental sounds such as shoes shuffling and knocks are too loud while music tracks are too low.  The overall effect is like watching a screening room print or watching a TV recorded theatrical production from masterpeice theater in the 1970's but with good resolution.Some of you may opt for the recent Sci-Fi channel mini-series.  It does address this film's flaws but it can be an awful flog to sit through such a long production.  The miniseries lacks the awe inspiring and unusual visual style of David Lynch's Dune; for this reason alone I recommend this title.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The novel Dune is far too complex to be compressed into the standard 2 or 3 hour movie.However, David Lynch has in fact successfully managed to summarize not only the basic story concept, but accurately captured the essence and spirit of the characters, the settings, and general atmosphere as depicted in Frank Herbert's most excellent book. The well-crafted soundtrack also greatly enhances this very worthy depiction, and a striking soundtrack can sometimes make all the difference for a film.Some purely cinematic improvisations were added in order to make an attempt to sell the film to the audience of the time (the use of sonic-enhanced energy weapons, etc.). This will be noted by erudite fans of Mr. Herbert's writing, but the end result was in fact fully endorsed by the author himself. As Herbert's stories are generally more inclined to be of the most intellectual aspects of science-fiction, they are not easily condensed into simple action-oriented features such as Star Wars and Star Trek.Dune...is merely chapter one in a series of ongoing novels, a tale of human evolution and human potential. Interweaving aspects such as  theology, ecology, political and military science, Dune was a book which actually needed a mini-series in order to put everything into perspective. This was finally done in 2000, but it lacks the power that Lynch's visually spectacular film presented.
summary: A story too complex for a standard movie

reviewText: This is actually a pretty good movie for something that seemed doomed from the start. Weird director directs Messiah obsessed Science Fiction novel  with epic overtones. Giant sandworms, characters thinking and oddly  disturbing undertones threaten to completely obliterate all  marketability.But for what it's worth Lynch pulls it off. Kyle  Maclachlin portrays a conflicted Paul Atriedes while the Harkonens are  completely odious. Creepy character actor Brad Dourif is just fascinating  while Sting isn't much more than a guy set up to get killed at the end of  the movie. The Toto music could be removed but its got its charms.If you  ignore the slightly incomprehensible backplot this is a fairly straight  forward movie about a young man exiled from his royal upbringings who  fights his way back and becomes leader of the galaxy. The spiritual mumbo  jumbo rendered so fascinating and realistic in the book is confusing in the  movie, but not so much that you can't follow it.One problem that I have  with this movie is the whispered voice-overs. WHile the book has a  character thinking something with every line he speaks, the movie renders  that a little too well and we have voice-overs from beginning to end which  may or may not be needed but are definitely irritating.So, decent movie.  Not as bad as some will have you believe. A very enjoyable couple of hours.

reviewText: I appreciate the movie, because it's not often a sci-fi movie does not become a horror B-movie. It looks beautiful on Blu-ray. I don't get the complaints about the dirt and specs, I did not notice them, and I have good eyesight.  It's strange people complain about perfectly good image quality while giving rave reviews to crappy presentations.  The review for "Rebecca" blu-ray image quality was unanimously good, but it looks like total crap, that kind of quality is not acceptable even for standard DVD.  The last 20 minutes or so has flashes and huge amount of specs it was unwatchable. I don't get it.
summary: The Blu-ray image quality is good

reviewText: The decimation of Frank Herbert's classic novel, DUNE can be found on DVD these days. How this movie even made it onto DVD is beyond me. It's pretty bad that Sting was probably the best actor in the film; his Harkonnen character is actually interesting to watch. However, the real pain comes in dismal performances by several actors, most notably Kyle MacLachlan. First of all, he seems to play the role of Paul Atreides in an immature fashion. I thought that Paul was supposed to be more serious? After all, is he not the "messiah?" His performance is frustrating and weak all around. I also didn't like the set for the film; if it's the year 10191, then why is everything crude-looking? Also, the narration was a bit annoying throughout the film, as if one is being updated due to their lack of understanding of what's going on. I will say that the sandworm sequences were done quite well, and the special effects are decent for 1984. Oh, and the music: dreadful at best, and that's not to knock Toto. It just didn't work for me. I was so pleased to see a mini series debut on the Sci-Fi Channel in 2000, and must say that it's a thousand times better than this $40 million catastrophe. Alec Newman is way better in the role of Paul, and I recommend viewing the mini series instead.

reviewText: Where to start with this movie?  The brilliant, but at times confusing sci-fi book series by Frank Herbert, on which this movie is based?  The equally brilliant, and idiosyncratic director, David Lynch?  The battle for supremacy between Lynch's theatrical cut of the film, and the recut-for-TV version upon which Lynch refused to bestow his name, leaving producers instead to credit the dreaded "Alan Smithee?"  This is a love-it or hate-it movie, as many other reviews have noted.  I felt some of both, so here goes.What I liked:  I will admit that part of my curiosity around this film was to answer the question, "is it even possible to make this book into a movie?"  The scenes and settings are so striking and original, the characters so unusual, and the plot so intricate and multi-layered, I tip my hat to Lynch simply for giving it a shot.  It's not possible to make this book into a film via literal scene-by-scene translation.  But I felt it was faithful to the book in all the ways that mattered.  BTW, musical score by the 70s/80s group Toto?  Affirmative (although the music feels somewhat dated at this point, I actually thought it was pretty good).What I didn't like:  Being an older film transfer, some of the quality issues are more apparent than in more recent films.  And I have to say I like Kyle MacLachlan as a general rule, but I thought he was wrong for this film, and not as convincing as Paul as some others might have been.  And Baron Harkonnen was just plain weird.But if you liked the book series, give it a shot.  . . . . but at least you won't be bored.

reviewText: Dune is a very long book so that it is hard to fit the elements into a film. The going rate is that a film can tell a short story.Dune is in reality the re-telling of the story of Mohamed. A person has some insights and finds some desert warriors to follow him. They have been trained to live through hardship and are able to defeat the corrupt forces of the Byzantine and Persian Empires although hopelessly outnumbered. They set up the Caliphate which dominates the world for hundeds of years.Dune is set on a desert planet and the hero of the story is the son of a merchant. His family have been given the planet which can generate enormous wealth as it produces something rare. The evil Harkonan family however want the planet back and they invade. Our hero is driven into the desert but stages a Geurilla war with the help of desert tribesman and not only regains his family plantet but the world.The problem with the film is that it is like a very potted summary of a long novel. In the novel the events define the characters and why they are good and bad. Because there is not time to do this in the film, the baddies are shown to be physically grotesque and addicted to eating live cows to establish that they are on the wrong side. The heroes are such because they look more attractive and dess more tastefully. The villians also live in a tasteless abode and have appalling manners. The heros also live in cooler pads and have more tasteful decorations.The book creates a sort of feudal society in which the main characters have endless sword fights. The basis of this is the invention of force field technology which makes projectile weapons inefective. In reality of course this is done so that Herbert can write a novel based on personal heroism rather than on characters who keep elaborate trading records. The film has a brief bizarre scene at the begining to illustrate this but then leaves the idea behind. One has the impression that a lot of editing has occured.What hits you about this film is the almost continually grotesque nature of the imagery and the very abreviated story. It is all pretty dreadful.

reviewText: Well, I missed the extended version on TV, so I was bound to get this at some point, even though I already had the existing DVD of the theatrical cut; I am a fan of the books ( only the ones written by Frank ).  As others have pointed out, the long version has been available overseas for some time now, but I only have a Region 1 player.Most of the new scenes are great.  About 16 minutes in they really get good.  However, the beginning is terrible.  Virginia Madsen has been virtually eliminated from the film, and replaced by a male narrator.  ( Sharp-eared fans may notice that part of her monologue from the theatrical cut can actually be heard during a certain scene in the extended cut... )  In place of the graphics used for the theatrical cut's "secret report within the Guild" we now have photography of artwork.  In some places ( especially the first battle for Arrakeen ) the sound mix seems to have really suffered from the original release.  Maybe this is due to the fact that it was presented for TV.  There is a bit of missing dialogue ( [Do you]"..know of the Water of Life?").  Entire scenes from the original film are absent from the extended cut, censored for the TV release ( I guess the Baron spitting in Jessica's face is just too much for the little kiddies ).  Perhaps most disturbingly, certain spaceship landing or flying shots are reused, often in completely inappropriate places.  There are new musical cues added, which are interesting in some places but unnecessary in others; in fact, the new cues seem to impede the original ones at times.  The early scene with the Guild navigator is somewhat ruined by a lack of the original voice and steam effects, as well as unnecessary added expository dialogue.  I should point out that all these issues date to the TV release; the extended cut on the DVD seems to be a faithful transfer of that version of the film.If you are a fan of the books, get this for the extended scenes, which are generally pretty good ( see Patrick Stewart rock out on the baliset!!! ).  If you're not into the extended scenes, the theatrical release is the definitive cut of this film.A word to the not-so-wise: when you say things like "the extended cut was not directed by David Lynch", pray tell, what in the name of Shai-Hulud do you mean by that?  Is it possible that a 2 hr.,57 min. extended version of a 2 hr.,17 min. David Lynch film could be directed by anyone other than David Lynch?  And while we're on that question, what is the meaning of "is"???Somebody get a Truthsayer in here STAT, these kids need some schoolin'!!!ALAN SMITHEE IS NOT A REAL PERSON!  ALAN SMITHEE IS THE NAME LISTED ON A FILM WHEN THE DIRECTOR WANTS THEIR NAME REMOVED FROM THE PROJECT!Reality check complete.  We now return you to your regularly scheduled misinformation.
summary: (sighs) the four stars are for the extended scenes only...
Title: N/A

reviewText: If you're a major Dune fan, ignore the bad reviews and pick this up, a steal for $20.00. David Lynch's Dune is a curiosity at best - it's a minor miracle that we've been given a SE with *any* bonus materials at all. Until the film itself is cleaned up and restored, this is as good as it gets. The four 5 minute featurettes are very well done and the image gallery is not bad.The Extended Edition of the film runs to almost 3 hours. It was put together by the studio (Universal) to be shown on television. They used to split it over two nights - factor in the commercial breaks and you'll understand why there's so much repitition in this cut. Music is hacked up and cut into scenes with very little care and some things could have been done better (like the prologue & narration). However, in this cut *much* that was missing is retored and overall the quality of the EE print is better than that of the theatrical cut included on this disc. The deleted scenes fill in more gaps.Yes, one day Lynch is going to have to face the fact that this film has fans who would love to see it fnally finished. It's happened to similar films (Blade Runner, Star Trek 1) so it may happen with Dune one day. Just by looking at what's on this disc, I'd say there's enough material to make an 'official' 3 hour cut that would be a major improvement over the theatrical cut.For now, this is THE dvd to get of the '84 Dune. Enjoy!

reviewText: It's still the best Dune. The look and feel of the movie are just right on the money. Jessica is perfect. This was also the last movie Sean Young made before she decided to become a flake, remember when she used to play sophisticated adult-type women, gang? Remember Blade Runner?The way they made futuristic technology look ancient really worked great. This is a feudal system, these oppulent items pass on for generations and it looks it. The sets and constuming sort of remind you of footage of the last Tsar of Russia. And when you want to film desert, nothing beats actually going out and filming some desert.Contrary to some of the reviewers on the New SCI-Fi miniseries, I thought the spaceship scenes were far better in this old version. They looked like the kind of spaceships super rich, royal dudes would have. That scene in the begining when the spaceships are docking with the guild transport is superbly done. You get the idea that they really are moving an entire planet's goods.Trivia: Jurgen Prochnow (Duke Leto) was almost killed in the making of this film. The book about the making of the movie is kind of interesting, too.

reviewText: I had enjoyed reading Frank Herbert's novel Dune back in the mid 1970's.  At that time the friend who introduced me to the novel and I wondered if a movie would ever be made of this wonderful book, and what that movie would be like.  We never imagined anything like this movie though!  The visual impact of some of the scenes in the movie are disturbing--from the bloated fish-like navigators, to the diseased Baron, to the animals put in service to the strange tastes of the Baron and his deranged nephews Raban and Feyd-Rautha.  But okay, Dune is a pretty weird book, with its medieval-flavored high-tech society where the heightened drug-induced capabilities of humans are forced to compensate for the religious sanctions against computers.  One should expect quite a few strange-looking beings in such a case.  The real problem with this movie is the enormous swath of events, plots, and subplots that it has to touch on to bring Paul Atreides from a boy in his teens to the warrior and messiah who brings a galactic empire to its knees.  This movie seems more like a bare outline of story rather than the story itself!  I am left to wonder if those who had not read the book could follow this movie at all!On the positive side, some of the roles were well cast.  Kyle Maclachlan was pretty much as I had imagined Paul Atreides--though it would seem that too many of his powers were focused on avoiding a bad hair day.  Sting captured the gleeful menace of Feyd-Rautha, and Max von Sydow endowed Liet-Kynes with the proper measure of gravitas.  The Baron, however, came off as a complete buffoon rather than an evil master strategist.  Duke Leto seemed somewhat stiff and lacking in the charisma that I felt that he should exude.  Lady Jessica was also somewhat stiff and did not exude the charm and sensuality that I had always associated with her.  I am not sure what might have been done with Alia--as a superwoman in a child's body--but the affect that they achieved was comic rather than threatening.One of the worst ideas implemented in this movie is the decision to color in all of the eyes of Paul and the other spice eaters so that their eyes (including the whites) are dark blue.  This effect gave the whole thing the look of an incredibly cheap production.  If the director or technical advisers were unable to use proper contact lenses or some other convincing-looking way of coloring eyes, they should have not colored the eyes of the spice eaters at all--as the coloring of the eyes from eating spice is hardly an essential plot element.
summary: Moves at a breakneck pace that may be hard to follow
Title: N/A

reviewText: As any film version of Dune, this 1984 release can hardly do justice to the epic novel that inspired it.  So in terms of living up to the title of "Dune" I do consider this movie something of a failure, but how well David Lynch tried!  His effort is obvious, and in some aspects he does indeed pull it off.The cast, special affects, and soundtrack to this movie were all superb.  Sting plays an excellent Feyd Rautha, and it's a shame his character didn't get more screen time.  Same with Patrick Stewart's rendition of the troubadour Gurney Halleck.  Kyle MacLachlan plays a passable Paul Atreides, and Sean Young is wonderful as Chani.  For 1984 the special affects were quite good as far as the sandworms were concerned, and they were brought to life very convincingly.  (the guild and the spaceships... well... not so good) It isn't Star Wars of course, but a solid effort nonetheless. Lastly, the music to the movie was surprisingly well done, and Toto (yes, remember them?) turns in a great performance.Now for a few criticisms . . . to begin with, this should probably have been released as a trilogy, as the story is simply too long, involved, and convoluted to make it possible to cram into a single episode.  For that reason, the plot moved erratically and sometimes inexplicably, and relied too much on semi-cheesy "thought" dialogue, where you could simply hear what was on a characters mind.  Key scenes were deleted (the knife fight with Jamis, Count Hasimir Fenring, to name a few) and several other bizarre and unnecessary changes were made (those silly sound-based weirding modules, the rain at the end?).  The erratic plot progression makes the movie rather difficult to watch, especially if one hasn't already enjoyed the novel.So overall I would rate this movie as a glorious failure, a picture that tries hard, has a few wonderful features, but just can't quite manage to pull it all together.  Flaws aside though, it's still an engaging film and a visual treat for any fans of Frank Herbert's universe of Dune.

reviewText: When I obtain the extended version I will have more to say.  For now, this is a pretty decent rendering of the novel, with some good casting and mostly impressive production design. reviewText: The movie is a visual and auditory delight.  Once you have the DVD, find a friend with a really good home theater, turn off the lights and crank up the volume.  You're in for a treat - sort of.The plot jumps from major event to major event.  Those who've actually read the book will be able to follow what's going on, but everyone else is going to be a little lost.  When I first saw this movie, 20 years ago, I remember thinking "that was great!  Imagine how good it would have been if the scriptwriter had actually read the book!"  This movie looks like Lynch got his script by reading the blurbs off of various Dune dust-jackets.There are major plot lines thrown in for no apparent reason.  For example, a big deal is made out of Paul Atreides drinking the "water of life" in order to become the "universe's super being."  And what does being the "universe's super being" get you?  It turns out that you get nothing.  The Emporer is conquered by Fremen riding Sand Worms and shooting imperial troops with "wierding modules."  Paul is just another guy riding a worm and shouting deadly Arrakeen words at fleeing figures so tiny that they look like stick figures.  (None of that is in the book incidentally - Lynch apparently got tired of the movie and needed any excuse to bring it to some sort of an end.) The samething happens when Paul has to rope himself a sandworm and ride it around - no reason for doing something this stupid is ever given.  Until the climatic battle scene described above, no one rides a worm - they walk in single file with a rhythm and cadence that would make a battalion of Marines proud.  (If you've read the books you know why that's a problem.)The movie itself has a number of bloopers and those are always fun.  Watch Gurney Halleck (Patrick Stewart) when he announces that he's walked in on Paul for "shield practice."  He hits the button on his belt for the shield, but nothing happens.  Apparently these erratic devices do this all the time, because no one notices.  Later, he gives the button a good slap and this time it works.  Must have to hit them just right...All that said, the movie is a classic, though imperfect, telling of a story too vast to tell in a single movie.  It would take something like Peter's Jackson's three movies breakout to even approach doing justice to this tale and, frankly, the audience base just isn't there.  I give the movie four stars for it's ambition and visual reach.  But do yourself a favor and read the book - you'll enjoy the movie a whole lot more!
summary: Beautiful sets, lighting & costumes ; A "Cliff Notes" Script

reviewerName: Wayne Klein "If at first the idea is not absu...
reviewText: Evidently fear of a long movie was the mindkiller for Universal and Dino De Laurentiis when it came to releasing David Lynch's "Dune" to theaters. Lynch managed to trim down his epic film to 2 hours and 17 minutes compressing Frank Herbert's marvelous, complex convoulted and massive novel into a single movie experience. There was lots of footage that ended up on the cutting room floor some of it deservedly so some not. Just be cautious if you purchase this at retail. Every copy save the one I purchased was loose in the tin packaging. Shake it and if you hear something bounding around don't buy it.What we get here is the "Ultimate" edition of the film so far. Lynch's original vision and on the flipside of this DVD18 the "Extended Version" that played on the Sci-Fi Channel. Both are presented in anamorphic widescreen (the extended edition for the first time). Both look good although there's lots of dirt and debris that could easily have been cleaned up by Universal. Instead they essentially used the same transfer as before for the theatrical version of the film. Colors are solid throughout for both versions. Sound is extremely good with a 5.1 mix for the first time on the extended version of the film. At three hours there is a certain amout of repetition of plot points (which is why some scenes were cut). It's a pity Lynch wasn't involved in the editing as he would have, no doubt, had a plan for reediting this material into a cohesive superior film.We get the following extras: deleted scenes with an introduction by producer Raffaella De Laurentiis. She disspells the myth that Lynch had a four hour version of the film ready to go and that it's floating around there somewhere. Certainly there was a rough cut but it wasn't anywhere near the finished condition necessary for release. No doubt it would have cost a lot to remix, redub (bringing back the actors) finish the effects (this was before CGI)and rescore. So what we have here is a compromise with both versions. We also have four excellent featurettes with plenty of clips, behind-the-scenes footage of Lynch shooting the movie. Lynch doesn't appear in any of the new featurettes nor does he provided a commentary as he clearly wasn't happy with the release of the extended version on DVD. The featurettes contain interviews with the visual effects supervisors discussing their work on the models, miniatures and the designers discussing the challenge of creating the costumes and the different "worlds" some of which Lynch had strong concepts about.The extended version for those who haven't seen it also includes a narrative that gives too much information although it duplicates part of the narration that Virginia Madsen does for the theatrical cut as Princess Irulan. The collectable tin case looks extemely good but if you buy this at retail shake them; I discovered a whole bunch where the discs were floating around loose inside. There's also a one sheet which gives the chapters, definitions (similar to the definition sheet given out in some theaters for the premiere)of the phrases and words used throughout the film and also a list of the extras.Personally, I prefer Lynch's vision flaws and all because the "Extended Edition" (put together by the studio without Lynch's involvement which is why the direction is credited to the ubiquitous "Alan Smithee" and the screenplay (also written by Lynch) to "Judas Booth". The extended edition has some moments that were lost that Lynch could have integrated into a new "Director's Cut" of the film if Univeral and Lynch could have come to agreement and it would have made Lynch's film, arguably, a better one but that didn't happen.
summary: Lynch's vision and Alan Smithee all on one disc
Title: N/A

reviewText: Dune, people said, was unfilmable.  Alexandro Jodorowsky (El Topo, the Holy Mountain) and Ridley Scott (Alien, Blade Runner) both tried, but  failed, to make the movie, unable to raise the massive budgets needed.  David Lynch succeeded.  Unfortunately.Lynch's Dune is bedecked with  problems.  It becomes overwhelmed by the sheer volume of information and  the size of the narrative, and Lynch's attempts to overcome these obstacles  are disastrous.  He chooses to do FAR too much exposition and character  thought "out loud," and the movie feels like a checklist of  important plot events from the novel.  Lynch fails to characterize anyone  but Paul, mistakes Paul for a great hero (instead of a great leader), and  apparently kills all the sandworms.  (Water, especially in the massive  rainfall at the ending, would do that.)  The love story with Chani and  Paul, for instance, is botched into a typical Hollywood auto-love, and  characters like Duncan Idaho and Liet Kynes are introduced, seemingly, just  to put in an appearance.  Paul, and only Paul, is a fairly well-rounded  character here.Read the book.  This movie's not worth your time.

reviewText: I heard a lot of good things about the movie,but when I saw it for the first time,I hated it.The acting was boring,I had to hit the fast forward button several times in order to find a good scene in the movie.Patrick Stewart was better in Excalibur,Star Trek,and the X-Men series,but Dune,NO.I am a big fan of the Police,and Sting.But his acting was not good in the movie.Kyle Maclachlan's character and acting was awful and so was his hairstyle.The only stars in the movie who were good were Sian Phillips and Max Von Sydov.He was good as Ming the Merciless in the Flash Gordon movie,Phillips was good as the Reverend Mother and in the Aristocrats.She deserve a better script.High marks do go for the special effects,costumes and props,but the acting and storyline didn't work.Perhaps many were cast in the wrong roles,or shouldn't be in the movie.I dozed off a couple of times.The two hours and fifteen minutes of the movie was B-O-R-I-N-G.I'm also still confused about the plot dealing with the giant worm.In closing the movie shouldn't be called DUNE.it should be called D-O-O-M.

reviewText: If I HAD to pick what I considered the "best SF novel so far", I would have to say it is DUNE.That in mind, when this movie version came out originally on VHS, I was mainly disappointed, yet appreciative of the effort.Over the years, I have probably seen this movie 20 times or more. Last week (March 2002), I watched the repulsive Dune TV mini-series. I then realised just how good the 1984 movie attempt is/was.OK, this movie does not follow the book exactly, and it is not possible to do the book justice in under 10 hours. The movie is lacking in its characterisation of a few of the second string characters such as Gurney Hallack, Duncan Idaho, Stilgar, etc etc.It, however, is excellently cast. The casted actors suit the characters wonderfully. Sting is excellent as Feyd, as are the actors who portrayed Paul, Alia, Jessica, the Duke, and escpecially the Australian actress who was Shaddap Mapps.I found "the voice" done excellently and I liked, and now appreciate even more, the way the characters' inner thoughts were portrayed to the viewer.I would have given this 3 to 4 stars in the past; but now having re-read the book (for the 20th time), watched the poor miniseries, and re-watched the VHS version, I now give this movie 5 stars.The DVD is on my birthday wish list!
Title: N/A

reviewText: If you are not familiar with the book 'Dune' you will be lost in the narrative of this film. As one who'd read the book I was lost some of the time. Welcome to the mind of director David Lynch.The script can't be blamed on him although I suspect somewhere in the editing room there are segments that would have made the story easier to follow.There are a few reasons this is a worthwhile film.a) it is visually interesting although it should be noted some effects seem terribly dated and/or ill suited for a Science Fiction filmb) if you can get past not understanding Dune the first pass it does become more comprehensible in future viewings.c) the acting is wildly varied with Kyle MacLachlan's characterization of Paul Atreides being wooden while Kenneth McMillan's portrail of Baron Vladimir Harkonnen is so over the top that you actually look forward to his pustule ridden face on screen.When first seeing Dune in a theater I walked away being impressed with the visual and sound aspects of the film. It is very much a David Lynch film so if you don't like his directing don't bother. Part of the problems with Dune are the script which is asked to take a complex novel with many characters and subplots and boil it down to a couple hours of entertainment.This has been done in the past but using Lord of the Rings 1 as an example, it took 3 hours to get the storylines and most of the characters together for a fine film. In Dune, Frank Herbert's novel, there was quite a bit of exposition on the politics and spirituality of the world he created. If pared down a good but incomplete story was possible. In the end this version of Dune chose to stay more comprehensive in plot with a loss of charater development and ability to comprehend the mostly linear exposition of the film.When watching it a few times there is a plot but it is rendered nearly inconcequential as the film drives along by looks and a few Lynchesque touches to the novel's characters. The one theme that came though was the bad guys have all the fun. They are the only happy people in the film for the vast majority of it's running time.Still, this is an enjoyable film and inventive where it can be. Consider it the anti-Star Wars.

reviewText: See subject... GREAT, iconic book, but bad film adaptation of same. One of director David Lynch's few disappointing works.  In his defense, Dune is nearly unfilmable, at least as a single movie.To dwell on this vast disappointment at all is very painful to me, so I'll just say it sucks and move on.Except to say, the ending... god. It is SO inexcusable and indefensible... a complete and utter slap in the face to any fan of the books. It RAINS?  "And now Muad'dib will bring love." Oh geez, straight Hollywooded-up BS. No other way to say it- F***  that.It doesn't even make logical sense, either. I really hope that part was the studio's idea, and not Lynch's.(To the ppl voting this review down, sorry, but if you'd read the book, you'd know that the movie blew chunks, and is not even within shouting distance of the standard of the book(s). And I say this as someone who LOVES both the book and most of David Lynch's work in general. They were two great tastes that somehow didn't taste great together.)

reviewText: I remember reading Dune when I was a teenager and being blown away by it. I instantly ran out and rented the movie and boy did it suck.  Now here I am 20 years later and I thought maybe this extended edition would be better.  Maybe the years that have passed will be much kinder to this version...nope, still sucked.  I read a lot of reviews on here about David Lynch legacy garbage...I could care less about the director, Santa Claus could have directed it for all I care as long as it's faithful to the novel.  This didn't accomplish it.  Don't even get me started on "Toto" doing the music.  I expected them to break out with "Africa" at any moment.  An epic story deserves an epic soundtrack.  And Sting....ug...nuff said.  Thank God Lord Of The Rings learned from the failure of movies such as this.  If you want to see a fairly faithful copy of Dune, rent the Mini-series from Sci-Fi.  Not great but it's the closest to Dune "story wise" out there.

reviewText: This movie made me go out and buy the books back in '84 when I saw it in the theater. I've recently become appreciative of the often underrepresented MacLachlan, whose intense vocal inflections and screen presence magnify the special effects and intricate storyline. It's one of those flicks I can deal with repeatedly and easily resist boredom. You get caught up in the interplanetary conspiracy and political intrigue, even amongst the psychic Bene Gesserit witches. This movie goes beyond escape from reality, into a spiraling journey through timespace--without moving. No spice required.
summary: MacLachlan Rules the Worm, Controls the Spice
